These historic reforms wouldn't be possible without the tireless work of survivors, advocates, veterans, and families like Vanessa's. We are indebted to them.

Now let's pass this bill and build the justice system that our service members deserve.

name: Kirsten Gillibrand
tweet_text: These changes will begin to restore faith in our military justice system and, hopefully, begin to shift the culture that has enabled the epidemic of sexual assault and harassment.

name: Kirsten Gillibrand
tweet_text:
That means that commanders won't be able to choose who serves on the jury, which expert witnesses can be called, or even whether to grant someone immunity.

Instead, those responsibilities will be given to trained, independent professionals.

name: Kirsten Gillibrand
tweet_text:
Far too many service members lost faith in our military justice system while untrained and potentially biased commanders had the power to act as judge and jury.

This year's defense bill will strip commanders of all remaining judicial and prosecutorial duties for covered crimes.

name: Kirsten Gillibrand
tweet_text:

name: Kirsten Gillibrand
tweet_text:
Here are a few more suggestions about how to debunk election misinformation shared by your friends and family.
https://t.co/rKc0Y5NGjF

name: Kirsten Gillibrand
tweet_text: Correcting misinformation can take time, and not everyone wants to be persuaded. But it's important to correct it when you can so everyone else in the group chat or reading the comments knows not to believe it and isn't discouraged from voting.

name: Kirsten Gillibrand
tweet_text: Ask who benefits if they don't vote. Remind them that their vote ALWAYS matters. Offer to help them find out where and when they can vote, or even to join them at the polls!

name: Kirsten Gillibrand
tweet_text: If a friend shares something that looks like misinformation, ask where they found it. Then redirect them to a reliable source, like https://t.co/PHRsglTlqF or your state board of elections. Be kind and keep it short, don't try to overwhelm them by sending multiple corrections.

name: Kirsten Gillibrand
tweet_text:
Election Day is just 1 week away, and foreign actors are already ramping up their efforts to push misinformation to discourage you from voting.

Once it's pushed out, this type of misinfo is often shared person-to-person in texts or on social media. Here's how you can debunk it. https://t.co/m3OF1qHUt0

name: Kirsten Gillibrand
tweet_text:
Cab drivers and public transit workers helped get people away from Ground Zero.

Ferries, tug boats, fishing boats, tour boats, and even party boats evacuated half a million people out of Manhattan ‚Äî a rescue operation larger than Dunkirk in World War II.

name: Kirsten Gillibrand
tweet_text:
Pilots, flight attendants, and passengers protected each other and fought the terrorists where they could.

Everyday people helped pull colleagues out of burning buildings, sometimes risking their own lives to save perfect strangers.

name: Kirsten Gillibrand
tweet_text: Today, as we honor her legacy, let us remember that Rosa Parks' story did not begin‚Äîor end‚Äîon December 1, 1955. Each of us must recommit every day to the fight against racism, injustice and inequality.¬†(4/4)

name: Kirsten Gillibrand
tweet_text: By the time of her now-famous act of civil disobedience in 1955, Rosa Parks was deeply involved in the struggle for civil rights in her community. She was‚Äîas she put it‚Äî"not tired physically....No, the only tired I was, was tired of giving in." (3/4)

name: Kirsten Gillibrand
tweet_text: Rosa Parks joined her local NAACP chapter in 1943 and was elected secretary‚Äîshe spent the next decade fighting to expand voting rights, secure justice for survivors of sexual assault, and desegregate public spaces (2/4)

name: Kirsten Gillibrand
tweet_text: On this day in 1955, Rosa Parks refused to give up her bus seat to a white man in Montgomery, AL. We often remember her for this act of defiance alone, which served as a catalyst for the Montgomery Bus Boycott. But she spent her life working to dismantle white supremacy (1/4) https://t.co/yAXqCZVod6

name: Kirsten Gillibrand

name: Kirsten Gillibrand
tweet_text: We need to apply some common sense and common decency to a broken process, and I am ready to fight for it. It‚Äôs what these service members and veterans need and deserve. 8/8

name: Kirsten Gillibrand
tweet_text: As you may know, I led a hard fight to get our 9/11 heroes the care they needed. Like our 9/11 heroes, these veterans answered the call of duty‚Äîfighting wars in Iraq and Afghanistan and elsewhere‚Äîand were made sick by their service. Now, our government should stand by them. 7/8

name: Kirsten Gillibrand
tweet_text:
To put it simply, this bill, The Presumptive Benefits for War Fighters Exposed to Burn Pits and Other Toxins Act, cuts the red tape. 

It says: If you served when the military used burn pits, and you are sick, you are covered. It should be that simple. 6/8

name: Kirsten Gillibrand
tweet_text: Now, these veterans are sick and dying. But they‚Äôre also fighting the VA for benefits, because the VA has placed on their shoulders the heavy burden of proof that their illness is linked to their service. Many are being denied benefits. My bill will change that. 5/8

name: Kirsten Gillibrand
tweet_text: The largest burn pit, on Balad Air Base in Iraq, was 10 acres of burning garbage, plastics, and medical waste. It burned 24 hours a day, 365 days a year, from 2003 to 2009‚Äînext to where our service members ate, slept, and worked. 4/8

name: Kirsten Gillibrand
tweet_text: These burn pits, so hazardous that they‚Äôre outlawed on American soil, were used on military bases around the world. More than three million service members‚Äîstationed in the Middle East, North Africa, and West Asia‚Äîhave likely been exposed to their carcinogens and toxic fumes. 3/8

name: Kirsten Gillibrand
tweet_text: During military operations in the Global War on Terror, the military employed open-air burn pits to burn garbage, medical waste, plastics, and other waste from military installations. Our service members lived and breathed in a toxic cocktail of dust, smoke, and debris. 2/8

name: Kirsten Gillibrand
tweet_text: THREAD: I‚Äôm announcing sweeping legislation to help veterans with diseases linked with exposures to #burnpits and other toxins. Many vets are sick and dying from these exposures‚Äîand the VA has made it difficult for them to get care. It‚Äôs an outrage. 1/8

name: Kirsten Gillibrand
tweet_text:
26 years ago, the Violence Against Women Act was signed into law, ensuring care for families suffering from domestic violence.

name: Kirsten Gillibrand
tweet_text: This #LaborDay, I‚Äôm thinking of the essential workers who remain at the frontlines of our country‚Äôs response to the COVID crisis. They deserve meaningful protections from Congress‚Äîincluding premium compensation, paid sick and family leave, and health and safety protections.

name: Kirsten Gillibrand
tweet_text: Enjoying your #LaborDay weekend? Thank a union. Unions have played critical roles in the fight for equality. They are our teachers, our nurses, our essential workers. We recommit to strengthening their power.

name: Kirsten Gillibrand
tweet_text: On #LaborDay, let‚Äôs recommit to our fight for policies that will support our working families year-round, like a national $15 minimum wage, paid family leave, strong unions and collective bargaining, and equal pay for equal work.

name: Kirsten Gillibrand
tweet_text: The pandemic has exposed just how much more we need to do to support American workers and their families. With millions struggling to make ends meet, we need to extend unemployment benefits, offer paid family leave and sick days, and address our ongoing hunger crisis. #LaborDay

name: Kirsten Gillibrand
tweet_text: In spite of the many challenges we face‚Äîand the work that remains to ensure that working families get the relief and support they deserve‚ÄîI hope that you and yours have a safe and restful Labor Day.

name: Kirsten Gillibrand
tweet_text: Millions of Americans have lost jobs, paychecks, and the ability to keep food on the table. Congress needs to extend desperately needed relief‚Äîfood assistance, rental assistance. We have the ability to alleviate suffering, let‚Äôs do it now.
